Title:
Genome phylogeny and evolutionary diversification of the
genus Picea
Keywords:
Picea, Transcriptome, phylogeny, introgression, incomplete
lineage sorting
Abstract:
The spruce genus (Picea), with around 38
species/varieties, occurs throughout the Northern Hemisphere from the
Arctic Circle to Mexico and Taiwan. Phylogenetic relationships within
the species remain unclear due to previous inconsistent results. In this
study, we carried out phylogenetic analyses of Picea species using
sequence variations from both plastome and nuclear genome from 26
species/varieties, including 16 from China, two from Europe, and eight
from North America. Our genome phylogenies indicate that the deepest
splits among surviving spruce lineages occurred in North America. Four
major clades, comprising two to nine species/varieties each, were
consistently recovered across all phylogenies. Plastome and nuclear
genome phylogenies contradict each other with respect to inter-clade
relationships, mainly in the placements of the North American P.
sitchensis and a clade comprising P. pungens, P. rubens and P. mariana.
These contradictions could mainly be the result of introgression of the
nuclear or chloroplast genomes from locally and adjacently distributed
species. However, incomplete lineage sorting and frequent interspecific
gene flow may, together, have contributed to further inconsistent
phylogenetic relationships between the closely related species within
two Eurasian clades. All these findings suggest evolutionary complexity
during diversification of the genus Picea.
